question: That horse had one good ball. That's all it takes.
answer: As Hochstetler looms on the horizon, plants himself like a tree in front of her.

question: I was sorry to hear about Jacob. Let us hope he walks close with God.
answer: I'm sure he does, Daniel. Daniel?

question: There'll be another train. The man who was killed tonight was a policeman, Sam. It's my job to find out who did it. I want you to tell me everything you saw when you went in there.
answer: I saw him.

question: Who'd you see? Who'd you see, Sam? The man on the floor?
answer: No... I saw the man who killed him.

question: Okay, Sam. Can you tell me what he looked like?
answer: He was... like him.

question: Black... I understand. What else,Sam?
answer: Not Zwartich, like him

question: I'll buy a dog. Go get a cup of coffee, Stan.
answer: How reliable is this kid?

question: Oh, he's good.
answer: Amish.

question: Yeah.
answer: What have you got?

question: Zenovitch was about to deliver a list of names tonight  street chemists... the guys processing this P2P into speed.
answer: So one of them got to him.

question: Maybe.
answer: You know who?

question: Maybe.
answer: You're still convinced there's a link to the department?

question: If there isn't I've just wasted the last six months.
answer: That's the problem. We need results. The press is driving us crazy over this P2P thing. Calling us the 'speed capitol of the country'. You know the sort of thing. It's getting political. The Commissioner's getting very uneasy.

question: The Amish boy saw him, Paul. I'll make it, but Set Donahue and the Homicide Department off my back or they'll blow the whole thing.
answer: When word gets out that Zenovitch was a cop, all hell will break lose. You've got 24 hours. That's all I can give you. 24 hours on your own. After that the case and the witness go back to the Homicide Department. Tell you what... why don't you and that blonde  what's-her-name  come over for dinner Sunday. How 'bout that.

question: What's-her-name moved to Buffalo.
answer: Well, anyway, don't get crazy. I'll do something for Zenovich's wife.

question: Where are you taking us?
answer: We're looking for a suspect. We've reason to believe he's still in the area.

question: You have no right to keep us here.
answer: Yes I do. Your son is a material witness to a homicide.

question: You don't understand, we have nothing to do with your laws!
answer: Doesn't surprise me. I meet a lot of people like that.

question: It's not a joke.
answer: You're right. It's not a joke. Listen, I know a little about the Amish. I know this has to be an ordeal for you; and I'm really sorry you an Samuel got involved. What was that?

question: He wants to know who you are. Your name. I told him we don't need to know anything about you.
answer: Book. John Book Sammy, where's Coalmine? Coalmine. Put some light on him. Look at him.

question: How could you do this to me tonight? I told you I had company
answer: Sorry. It's important. Where's Timmy and Buck?

question: Upstairs, asleep. Where'd you think?
answer: You've got a man here and the kids are upstairs?

question: That's none of your goddamn business! So keep your goddamn holier-than- thou mouth shut! Anyway, they like Fred.
answer: Oh sure, Fred.

question: Who are these orphans, anyway?
answer: They're Amish.

question: Everything okay?
answer: Yes, thank you very much.

question: John said you're Amish.
answer: Yes.

question: Jesus...
answer: Good morning.

question: You didn't have to...
answer: I wanted to. you were kind to take us in last night. Anyway, I needed something to do. I was so angry with your brother. He's so... agaanisish!

question: Aganishish? Yeah, that sounds like John.
answer: Just a minute. I'll pour you some coffee.

question: You're not carrying a bullwhip... how'd you manage to put my kids to work?
answer: I made it a contest... the one who does best gets his cereal back first. Children like to help... they only need to be kept after a little bit.

question: Oh, is that so? No offense, lady, but I'm not so sure I like the idea of your coming in here and turning the place upside down!
answer: Please, I didn't mean...

question: I know exactly what you meant! Listen, maybe I'm not a world-class housefrau, but maybe I don't have time to polish the goddamn china and keep after the kids! It's none of your business, but I don't happen to have a man around here full time. So I sell cosmetics in a goddamn drugstore and sometimes I can even pay the rent on time! So maybe I'm not Mary Poppins, but maybe I don't need to have it jammed down my throat like this. There is that clean enough for you? Go to hell, Fred!
answer: I brought your coffee. I'm sorry. I didn't mean it that way.

question: It's okay. Look, I shouldn't have blown my top. It's like... somehow... I've let everything get away from me. And you sort of made me face it. What's so funny?
answer: Fred. The way he looked when you screamed at him.

question: God, Fred...
answer: At home you'd never hear a woman scream at a man that way.

question: No? Why not?
answer: You just wouldn't. It's not the Amish way. But I think it would have done me good if I could have screamed at your brother last night.

question: Listen, I don't know what's going on or how you got mixed up with him, but don't you let that self-righteous son of a bitch push you around, okay?
answer: Okay.

question: Okay.
answer: Now what's the problem?

question: The problem is I don't happen to think my son should be spending all his time with a man who carried a gun under his coat and goes around whacking people.
answer: Whacking?

question: Yes. And I also want to leave this city.
answer: Believe me, I'm trying to get this over with as fast as I can. But Samuel will probably have to come back and testify.

question: We do not go into your courts.
answer: People who don't go into our courts when they're told to sometimes go directly into our jail. Look, I'm genuinely sorry...

question: No you're not  You're glad, because now you've got a witness. I heard the other police talking last night. They don't seem to like you very much.
answer: They kid a lot.

question: I would not be too sure. He says you look very tired. I thought the same thing. But not a good tired.
answer: What's a 'good' tired. Tired is tired.

question: Just wanted to see if you were on your toes.
answer: Your sister said you don't have a family?

question: No.
answer: She thinks you should get married and have children of your own. Instead of trying to be a father to hers. Except she thinks you're afraid of the responsibility.

question: Oh? Anything else?
answer: Oh yes. She thinks you like policing because you think you're right about everything. And you're the only one who can do anything. And that when you drink a lot of beer you say things like none of the other police would know a crook from a... um... bag of elbows. I think that's what she said. Good appetite.

question: Afternoon, gentlemen. I'd like you to meet Samuel Lapp. We'd like a little help.
answer: Why don't you arrest that man? Are you protecting him because policeman?

question: Listen, I'm the cop that polices the police. I'm not in the business of protecting crooked cops. I'll make an arrest when I know everybody involved.
answer: But why would they murder...

question: Because  somehow  they knew I was getting close. Look, it's narcotics... They make dope out of chemicals... they sell it on the street for millions of dollars. They'll do anything. And they can get away with it because they're cops.
answer: I'm afraid. I'm afraid for Samuel. I want to go home.

question: You'll be safe. You don't have to worry. Look, they're thinking as long as they keep the killer out of Samuel's way, we can't make an I.D. There's no way they can know Samuel saw that photograph, so he's safe. I mean it. You will be safe.
answer: Oh yes! Of Course. Why shouldn't we feel safe in a city where the police are so busy killing each other!

question: It was McElroy, Paul. Last guy I would have figured. But he's part of it.
answer: I hope you don't have any doubts about that.

question: If I did, I'd have kept my mouth shut... It fits, Paul... Fifty-five gallons of P2P confiscated four years ago... Guess who was in on the collar? Mac. He salts it away somewhere... he knows the stuff is potent, but the street chemists haven't figured out how to process it. But they do now. And now the stuff is worth five-grand a pint and there are a lot of pints in a fifty-five gallon drum.
answer: Who else knows?

question: Just us.
answer: Okay, what are you going to need to clean it up

question: More people... Gotta pick up where Zenovich left off. People from outside the department.
answer: Maybe the Bureau. Or those bastards at Treasury. I'll take care of it. I hate this shit, Johnny. You cut their balls off for me. I'm counting on you. What's your first move?

question: Still smiling, he brings up his right hand out of a shopping bag  letting the shopping bag fall away as he does so  revealing a five-inch barrel Smith and Wesson .357 blue finish revolver with a silencer. Without hesitating, coming right on, still smiling, he FIRES once.
answer: Already starting to leap away to one side, he is hit, driven into a half-turn. He clutches at the wound, as:

question: Coming right on, FIRING again... the pistol's report a WHOOSHING, like the opening of a bottle of cheap champagne. And McElroy still smiling as:
answer: Hit... a grazing near-miss this time, but enough to send Book down hard and grasping.

question: Lowering the pistol alongside his leg, as two MEN, barely taking notice of anything, cross with their backs to Book toward McElroy.
answer: Down, muttering CURSES.

question: Yeah...
answer: Listen carefully, I wrote the Amish woman's name and address on my desk calendar, I want you to lose it for me, Now. Tonight.

question: What the hell are you talking about? What's happening.
answer: Nothing. I'm not going to be around for a while. I'll call you when I can.

question: Johnny, what the fuck?
answer: Listen to me  Schaeffer's part of it. Maybe at the top of it. Yeah... I can put it all together when I get back, 'Til then, you know nothing, understand? Business as usual...

question: I hear you.
answer: Good. Take care of that woman's name for me. And watch your ass.

question: Good. Take care of that woman's name for me. And watch your ass.
answer: It's John. He says you have to leave now. He says it's urgent.

question: Put my car in the garage and close the door.
answer: John, I don't understand any of this.

question: You don't know anything... borrowed your car. Didn't say why. And you never heard of that woman and her boy.
answer: John, why?...

question: But John... why didn't you go to a hospital?
answer: No, no doctor...

question: But why?
answer: Gunshot... they'll file reports... they'll find me.

question: But
answer: And when they find me, they'll find your boy!

question: Go help Levi with the car, Samuel. No, he must stay here.
answer: Didn't you hear Stoltzfus? What if he dies? Then the sheriff will come. They'll say we broke their laws

question: We'll pray that he doesn't die! But if he does, then we'll find a way so no one knows!
answer: Rachel, this is a man's life, we hold it in our hands.

question: Looks like we're going to need some help from you folks down there.
answer: ...want to help any way we can, Chief, but you got to understand we've got upwards of seven thousand Amish over here.

question: I've got the woman's name, Sheriff. Lapp. Rachel Lapp. That should simplify your work.
answer: How about an address?

question: Ah... no.
answer: Maybe a road or route number?

question: Sorry.
answer: Problem is, Chief, 'bout every third Amishman around here is named Lapp. That or Yoder. Or Hochstetler. Chief, if the Amish have taken your man in, I wouldn't want to hang from a rope until you find him.

question: Hello.
answer: Who are they?

question: The leadership of our district... the diener. Bishop Tschantz is the one with no hair on top. They decided to come and see you for themselves. Except Stoltzfus, of course. He came the first day. I think he saved your life.
answer: Can I have something to drink? Does anybody know I'm here?

question: Only the elders.
answer: How long?

question: What?
answer: How long have I been here?

question: Two days.
answer: Listen, thank you. Thanks for everything. But I've got to go.

question: Did you find him?
answer: Not yet.

question: Then go away, you bastard.
answer: Elaine, I've come to apologize for Lt. McElroy. He overstated the department's position.

question: He accused John of taking kickbacks. And you know  anybody who knows John  knows that's a goddamn lie!
answer: Of course, Elaine. But as long as there's any question, better Johnny should come back and clear his name.

question: Better you should get off my front porch before I get my mace!
answer: Elaine, I don't want to have to take you in for questioning. You've got his car, you were the last to see him

question: I don't know where he is.
answer: But... if you had to guess?

question: But... if you had to guess?
answer: She say where he is?

question: I don't think she knows. What about Carter?
answer: Tight. But I'm working on him.

question: His eyes are open and watching Samuel icily, which gives the boy something of a jolt. Give me that. Come here. You ever handle a pistol like this, Samuel?
answer: No pistol. Ever.

question: Tell you what  I'm going to let you handle this one. But only if you promise not to say anything to your momma. I've got a feeling she wouldn't understand.
answer: Okay, Mr. Book.

question: Call me John. You don't want to point that at people you just started calling by their first name.
answer: Samuel! Wait for me downstairs. John Book, I would appreciate it if, during the time you are with us, you would have as little to do with Samuel as possible.

question: Nobody meant any harm. The boy was curious. I unloaded the gun -
answer: It's not the gun. Don't you understand... It's you. What you stand for. That is not for Samuel. Please, it has nothing to do with you personally.

question: The gun  that gun of the hand  is for the taking of human life. Would you kill another man? Eh? What you take into your hands, you take into your heart.
answer: I would only kill a bad man.

question: Only a bad man. I see. And you know these bad men on sight? You are able to look into their hearts and see this badness?
answer: I can see what they do. I have seen it.

question: Enjoying your reading?
answer: Very interesting. I'm learning a lot about manure. What's that?

question: Your shirt and jacket are still stained with blood. I have them soaking.You can wear these.
answer: Your husband's?

question: Yes. It's good that someone can have the use of them. Besides, in your clothes you'd stand out to strangers. I should tell you these do not have buttons. See? Hooks and eyes.
answer: Something wrong with buttons?

question: Buttons are Hochmut.
answer: Hochmut?

question: Vain. Proud. Such a person is Hochmutsnarr. He is not plain.
answer: Anything against zippers?

question: You make fun of me. Like the tourists. Driving by all the time. Some even come into the yard. Very rude. They seem to think we are quaint.
answer: Quaint? Can't imagine why. Where's the nearest telephone?

question: Telephone? The Gunthers across the valley. They're Mennonite. They have cars and refrigerators and telephones in the houses even.
answer: No. I'd want a public phone.

question: Well... the store at Saltzburg... But you won't be going to Saltzburg for a while.
answer: I'm going this morning.

question: But Stoltzfus said...
answer: I know what he said.

question: You can go with Eli. He's taking Samuel to school. But you'll have to hurry.
answer: Rachel. Thanks.

question: Not much good without them.
answer: Yeah?

question: It's me.
answer: Johnny! Where the hell have you been?

question: Never mind. I'm coming in to take care of business. How hot am I?
answer: Too hot. Don't do it. Don't come in.

question: I'm coming.
answer: Listen, Johnny, don't do anything stupid. You couldn't get within a mile of Schaeffer right now. So stay put... Stay in touch  I'll let you know when maybe it makes sense. You hear me?

question: I hear you. I'll stay in touch.
answer: That's more like it. Where are you at, anyway?

question: Where I'm at is maybe 1890.
answer: Say again?

question: Make that 1790.
answer: If you are well enough to do that thing, you can do work for me.

question: Sure, I'm sorry. Hope you don't mind me plugging in to your battery. Mine's dead... How can I help? What can I do?
answer: Maybe milking.

question: Milking?
answer: Cows. You know, cows?

question: I've seen pictures.
answer: Good, you start tomorrow. Veck oufl. Time for milking.

question: Good morning. Book, is it? You are the Yankee they talk about?
answer: I thought I was the English.

question: English, Yankee. It's the same. My name is Daniel. Daniel Hochstetler. You look plain, Book. Very plain. I came to see Rachel Lapp.
answer: Try the house.

question: Pigs. He uses a drawknife on a piece of 2x4, with some obvious expertise.
answer: Eli is a fine carpenter. Best in the district. He and his father built the big house themselves forty years ago.

question: Oh? What happened to Hochstetler?
answer: We had some lemonade and he left.

question: A real fireball.
answer: You know carpentry?

question: I did some carpentry summers when I was going to school.
answer: What else can you do?

question: I can whack people. I'm hell at whacking.
answer: Whacking is not of much use on a farm.

question: Now hold on. There's a lot of people who think being a cop is a legitimate job.
answer: I'm sorry. I'm sure it is. Tonight I'll let out those trousers for you.

question: Sure.
answer: But... You may not be well enough.

question: I'll drink some more of Stoltzfus' tea. Hi...
answer: When will you be going?

question: Not long... A few days. You like it... Don't you?
answer: No... You just stop

question: How can this be? How can you do such a thing? Is this plain? Is this the ordnung?
answer: I have done nothing against the ordnung.

question: Eh? Nothing? Rachel, you bring this man to our house. With his gun of the hand. You bring fear to this house. Fear of English with guns coming after. You bring blood and whispers of more blood. Now English music... and you are dancing to English music! And you call this nothing?
answer: I have committed no sin.

question: No sin? Maybe. Not yet. But, Rachel, it does not look... Don't you know there has been talk? Talk about you, not him. Talk about going to the Bishop. About having you... shunned!
answer: That is idle talk.

question: Do not make light of it, Rachel. They can do it... quick! Like that! And then... then I can not sit at table with you. I can not take a thing from your hand. I... I can not go with you to meeting! Rachel, good Rachel, you must not go too far! Dear child!
answer: I am not a child.

question: You are acting like one!
answer: I will be the judge of that.

question: No! They will be the judge of that! And so will I... if you shame me!
answer: You shame yourself.

question: You know where he is.
answer: Wrong.

question: You'd lie to protect him.
answer: Probably.

question: You admit you're lying?
answer: I admit I don't know where he is.

question: You're the first one he'll contact.
answer: He's got my number.

question: It's funny. I know he's hiding somewhere with the Amish, I know it. Can you imagine John Book at a prayer meeting? Our John Book? Either you're a member of the club or you aren't, Elton. Tell me what you know...
answer: What I know, Paul, is... He's going to take you out...

question: Uh oh, they're leaving us behind. Lady, if you take my picture, I'll rip your brassiere off and strangle you with it. Lieutenant Elton Carter, please. What? I'm a friend of his.
answer: I'll take it in the study. You can hang up, dear.

question: You made a mistake, Paul. You shouldn't have taken Elton out.
answer: How bad did Mac get you? We figured pretty bad.

question: I'm fine. I'm going to live a long time. That's what I called to tell you.
answer: Johnny

question: You might want to pass it along to Mac.
answer: Listen to me, Johnny. Come in! You're out there all alone... We're getting close... real close... Maybe if you listen to me for a minute we can work something out so you can come in

question: Pick up the hat.
answer: He's from... Ohio... My cousin. John, lost control of himself. He... will be repentant. Yes. Samuel! We're going. You should not bother with that birdhouse. If you're leaving tomorrow.

question: I'm leaving tonight. I'm going to need my clothes. And my gun.
answer: There was a time when I thought you might have stayed.

question: There was.
answer: There was a time when I would have welcomed it.

question: I know.
answer: I was being foolish?

question: No. I was being unrealistic. Even thinking about living this life.
answer: You're so sure of that?

question: Aren't you? After today?
answer: I'm not so sure of anything as you are, John Book. You could live this life if you wanted to bad enough. Just as I could live yours!

question: Oh, come on, Rachel. No way.
answer: There is always a way! But you are such a... a Glotzkopp you cannot see! You'd rather go back to that city! To nothing! No woman! No children! No land!

question: Land! Are you crazy? I'm no Amishman and I'm no farmer! I'm a cop. That's what I know and that's what I do!
answer: What you do is take vengeance! Which is a sin against heaven!

question: That's your way, not mine.
answer: That's God's way!

question: Well in the City of Philadelphia, God needs a little help!
answer: I could never love a man who was so... little. The other night... when you saw me after my bath... I... I tried to look as I thought you would want a woman to look. I am sorry... that I did not.

question: Looking after her. A face full of loss.
answer: Eli, would you see Samuel to bed?

question: Is it them?
answer: It's them, Sam. Now, Sam, listen to me and listen to me carefully. Listen to me as you never listened before.

question: Are they going to kill you?
answer: Listen to me, Sam! I want you to go across the new corn to Stoltzfus'. Run as fast as you can. And stay there!

question: What are you going to do?
answer: I'll be all right. You just do as I say.

question: Don't let them hurt you.
answer: I won't. Now run. Fast as you can! As he listens, tenses, hearing Fergie's feet in the fresh straw. As he slips out of the stall, ducks toward the rear of the barn.

question: Hey, Mac!
answer: As he turns toward the SOUND of Book's voice. Eyes darting wildly, looking up. Diving to one side. Staring at the fork pop-eyed.

question: Sprinting toward a ladder thrust up through an opening in the barn floor just in front of his parked car.
answer: Spotting Book, coming up to one knee, quick-aiming, FIRING. The shot smashes the windshield of the car.

question: Diving, rolling, slamming into the top of the ladder, flailing down out of sight.
answer: FIRING AGAIN, then again. Emptying the gun, cursing as he begins to reload, gets to his feet, starts toward the ladder. The BELL still SOUNDING outside. The hood of the car SLOWLY

question: Comes hesitantly down the path toward the barn, looking toward the sound of the bell, but also looking back in glances toward the house to make sure Rachel and Eli stay where they are. He still can't see Samuel. Turning, SHOUTING: You stay put!
answer: She stops. She is also unable to see Samuel.

question: Moving out toward the barn, rounding a corner... and there is Samuel at the bellrope. He starts toward him. Cut that out! Get down to the house and stay there!
answer: Already halfway out to the barn, running to gather Sam in her arms... then to lead him back toward the house.

question: Moving among the cows, stepping cautiously between the cowflops. Climbing with difficulty, shotgun clutched in one hand.
answer: He climbs up to the second kickboard, pauses, checks the distance to the floor, starts upward again.

question: Rattling up the other ladder, approaching the third kickboard.
answer: Listening tensely, hearing McElroy arrive on the other side of the kickboard. Then, deliberately, Book makes a fist, raps on the board smartly once.

question: Startled, REACTING. He sets his feet, leans back against the back wall of the ladder well, brings the shotgun up, puts the muzzle against the kickboard, clicks off the safety.
answer: We HEAR with him the thump of the muzzle, the CLICK... and, with marvelous speed, Book pulls the kickboard and drops it to the floor.

question: Turning, looking into the crowd, finding Rachel. Their gazes meet, hold for a long MOMENT. In the eyes of both we read resignation... whatever there was between them has been terribly damaged. It is almost certainly over for them, too.
answer: Are you really ever coming back?

question: Got to, Sam. You and I are going to a courthouse together, put some people behind bars.
answer: Have you got your gun on now?
